get.description: Retrieves a range of audit logs. If no further audit logs are currently available, the data array will be empty. As new audit logs are created, subsequent requests using the same next_page value will be in the returned data array, ensuring a continuous and uninterrupted reading of audit logs.

parameters.name: starting_on
parameters.description: RFC 3339 timestamp of the earliest audit log to return. Cannot be used with 'next_page'.

parameters.name: ending_before
parameters.description: RFC 3339 timestamp (exclusive). Cannot be used with 'next_page'.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: Sort order by timestamp, e.g. date_asc or date_desc. Defaults to date_asc.

parameters.name: resource_id
parameters.description: Optional parameter that can be used to filter which audit logs are returned. If you specify resource_id, you must also specify resource_type.

parameters.name: resource_type
parameters.description: Optional parameter that can be used to filter which audit logs are returned. If you specify resource_type, you must also specify resource_id.

next_page.description: The next_page parameter is always returned to support ongoing log retrieval. It enables continuous querying, even when some requests return no new data. Save the next_page token from each response and use it for future requests to ensure no logs are missed. This setup is ideal for regular updates via automated processes, like cron jobs, to fetch logs continuously as they become available. When you receive an empty data array, it indicates a temporary absence of new logs, but subsequent requests might return new data.

UniquenessKey.description: Prevents the creation of duplicates. If a request to create a record is made with a previously used uniqueness key, a new record will not be created and the request will fail with a 409 error.

UniquenessKeyForCommitsAndCredits.description: Prevents the creation of duplicates. If a request to create a commit or credit is made with a uniqueness key that was previously used to create a commit or credit, a new record will not be created and the request will fail with a 409 error.

BalanceForCommitsAndCredits.description: The current balance of the credit or commit. This balance reflects the amount of credit or commit that the customer has access to use at this moment - thus, expired and upcoming credit or commit segments contribute 0 to the balance. The balance will match the sum of all ledger entries with the exception of the case where the sum of negative manual ledger entries exceeds the positive amount remaining on the credit or commit - in that case, the balance will be 0. All manual ledger entries associated with active credit or commit segments are included in the balance, including future-dated manual ledger entries.

name.description: The display name of the billable metric.

sql.description: The SQL query associated with the billable metric

archived_at.description: RFC 3339 timestamp indicating when the billable metric was archived. If not provided, the billable metric is not archived.

name.description: The display name of the billable metric.

sql.description: The SQL query associated with the billable metric. This field is mutually exclusive with aggregation_type, event_type_filter, property_filters, aggregation_key, and group_keys. If provided, these other fields must be omitted.

aggregation_key.description: Specifies the type of aggregation performed on matching events. Required if `sql` is not provided.

custom_fields.description: Custom fields to attach to the billable metric.

PropertyFiltersArray.description: A list of filters to match events to this billable metric. Each filter defines a rule on an event property. All rules must pass for the event to match the billable metric.

AggregationType.description: Specifies the type of aggregation performed on matching events.

AggregationKey.description: A key that specifies which property of the event is used to aggregate data. This key must be one of the property filter names and is not applicable when the aggregation type is 'count'.

GroupKeysArray.description: Property names that are used to group usage costs on an invoice. Each entry represents a set of properties used to slice events into distinct buckets.

in_values.description: A list of event types that are explicitly included in the billable metric. If specified, only events of these types will match the billable metric. Must be non-empty if present.

not_in_values.description: A list of event types that are explicitly excluded from the billable metric. If specified, events of these types will not match the billable metric. Must be non-empty if present.

EventTypeFilter.description: An optional filtering rule to match the 'event_type' property of an event.

name.description: The name of the event property.

exists.description: Determines whether the property must exist in the event. If true, only events with this property will pass the filter. If false, only events without this property will pass the filter. If null or omitted, the existence of the property is optional.

in_values.description: Specifies the allowed values for the property to match an event. An event will pass the filter only if its property value is included in this list. If undefined, all property values will pass the filter. Must be non-empty if present.

not_in_values.description: Specifies the values that prevent an event from matching the filter. An event will not pass the filter if its property value is included in this list. If null or empty, all property values will pass the filter. Must be non-empty if present.

PricingGroupKey.description: For USAGE products only. If set, pricing for this product will be determined for each pricing_group_key value, as opposed to the product as a whole. The superset of values in the pricing group key and presentation group key must be set as one compound group key on the billable metric.

PresentationGroupKey.description: For USAGE products only. Groups usage line items on invoices. The superset of values in the pricing group key and presentation group key must be set as one compound group key on the billable metric.

tags.name: Customers
tags.description: [Customers](https://docs.metronome.com/provisioning/create-customers/) in Metronome represent your users for all billing and reporting. Use these endpoints to create, retrieve, update, and archive customers and their billing configuration.

tags.name: Billable metrics
tags.description: [Billable metrics](https://docs.metronome.com/understanding-metronome/how-metronome-works#billable-metrics) in Metronome represent the various consumption components that Metronome meters and aggregates. These metrics appear as line items and sub-line items on an invoice and each has a unique price per unit.

tags.name: Usage
tags.description: [Usage events](https://docs.metronome.com/connecting-metronome/send-usage-data/) are the basis for billable metrics. Use these endpoints to send usage events to Metronome and retrieve aggregated event data.

tags.name: Products
tags.description: Products are the items that customers purchase.

tags.name: Rate cards
tags.description: Rate cards are used to define default pricing for products.

tags.name: Contracts
tags.description: Contracts provide an alternative to plans for provisioning and invoicing customers. Use these endpoints to create and update contracts data.

tags.name: Credits and commits
tags.description: Credits and commits are used to manage customer balances.

tags.name: Invoices
tags.description:
[Invoices](https://docs.metronome.com/invoicing/) reflect how much a customer spent during a period, which is the basis for billing. Metronome automatically generates invoices based upon your pricing, packaging, and usage events. Use these endpoints to retrieve invoices.
 NOTE: The `invoice_adjustments` array can include credit deductions, invoice minimums, credit grant conversions, and trial deductions; to identify credit deductions, check for the `credit_grant_id` field.

tags.name: Alerts
tags.description: [Alerts](https://docs.metronome.com/connecting-metronome/alerts/) monitor customer spending, balances, and other billing factors. Use these endpoints to create, retrieve, and archive customer alerts. To view sample alert payloads by alert type, navigate [here.](https://docs.metronome.com/manage-product-access/create-manage-alerts/#webhook-notifications)

tags.name: Custom fields
tags.description: [Custom fields](https://docs.metronome.com/integrations/custom-fields/) enable adding additional data to Metronome entities. Use these endpoints to create, retrieve, update, and delete custom fields.

tags.name: Security
tags.description: [Security](https://docs.metronome.com/developer-resources/security/) endpoints allow you to retrieve security-related data.

tags.name: Settings
tags.description: Use these endpoints to configure a billing API key, a webhook secret, or invoice finalization behavior.
